<a rel='month origin' value='12'>December</a> <a rel='day origin' value='27'>27th</a> [<a href='/results.php?city=charleston' rel='city origin'>CHARLESTON</a>, S. C., <a href='/results.php?year=1860' rel="origin">1860</a>]. Mrs. Gidiere came in quietly from her 
marketing to-day, and in her neat, incisive manner exploded this bombshell : <a href='/results.php?tla=roa' rel=''>Major Anderson</a> has moved into Fort Sumter, while <a href='/results.php?tla=wfp' rel='acquaintance met'>Governor Pickens</a> slept serenely." The 
row is fast and furious now. State after State is taking its forts and fortresses. They say if we had been left out in 
the cold alone, we might have sulked a while, but back we would have had to go, and would merely have fretted and 
fumed and quarreled among ourselves. We needed a little wholesome neglect. Anderson has blocked that game, but 
now our sister States have joined us, and we are strong. I give the condensed essence of the table-talk : Anderson 
has united the cotton States. Now for Virginia ! " Anderson has opened the ball." Those who want a row are in 
high glee. Those who dread it are glum and thoughtful enough. 
</p><p>

us. We stand in need of Avise counsel; something more than courage. The talk is : Fort Sumter must be taken ;
